newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-ZOFF REPORTED INTERESTED IN ITALY COACH JOB.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-ZOFF REPORTED INTERESTED IN ITALY COACH JOB.

text.p: Dino Zoff, who led Italy to World Cup victory in 1982, is interested in coaching the national team, former team mate Fulvio Collovati said on Wednesday.
Speaking on Telepiu 2 pay television, Collovati said he had spoken to Zoff recently and discussed the job left vacant when Arrigo Sacchi resigned suddenly on Sunday night.

"I was able to speak to Zoff yesterday and he confirmed his interest, he indicated he was willing to sit on the bench," said Collovati, who played with Zoff in the team that beat West Germany 3-1 in Madrid for the world title.
"From what I saw, he is keen. I think that after December 14, Zoff will be called," the ex-Milan defender said.
December 14 is the date when the Italian soccer federation meets to elect Luciano Nizzola as its new chairman.

Nizzola confirmed on Wednesday that he would announce the name of the new coach as soon as possible after the election but not necessarily that very day. "It's something I will do as soon as possible, on the 14th, 15th or 16th."

He said there were no candidates other than those well documented by the media -- meaning Zoff, under-21 coach Cesare Maldini, former Parma coach Nevio Scala and the seemingly unavailable Giovanni Trapattoni and Fabio Capello.
Capello and Trapattoni have both publicly ruled themselves out of the running since Sacchi resigned.
Zoff, the most capped player in Italian soccer history with 112 appearances, is currently Lazio president and has not coached actively for more than two years.
Nizzola is known to be a great admirer of the former goalkeeper and Zoff's name has the status and weight that Italy, going through a poor patch internationally, need.
